content: @WG-rustc-dev-guide :wave: the meeting will be starting in ~ 14 minutes
What's the process /platform for joining?
It's just going to be here on Zulip I think
yeah, here
Ah okay, I was thinking it might be audio/video. :+1:
@WG-rustc-dev-guide :wave:, let's get this started ...
the idea of the meeting is to "plan" a bit the work of the walkthrough section
to remember a bit to everyone, the original idea of this section was ...
having a chapter that shows a walkthrough of the stages from the compiler's perspective
so maybe having Rust code examples and show what happens to that code in each different stage of the compiler
we've discussed this before a bit, let me find the link
like what's the output of that stage, what's the main structures and how they look like
yeah
https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/196385-t-compiler.2Fwg-rustc-dev-guide/topic/let's.20organize.20walkthrough.20section.20work ?
We can talk about this later, but we might want to change the name since IMO it's a bit general
and https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/196385-t-compiler.2Fwg-rustc-dev-guide/topic/meeting.202020.2E10.2E27/near/214756334 too

Camelid said:

We can talk about this later, but we might want to change the name since IMO it's a bit general

how do you mean?
"walkthrough" sounds to me like a "Getting Started" section (which we have)
Maybe "compiler walkthrough" would be clearer
Because otherwise it could be "walkthrough of contributing" or something
I think we would be good if in this meeting we properly define what we want to accomplish and maybe have a couple of next steps and things that we can start tackling
ah good point - maybe "A tour of the compiler" or something like that
"compilation process walkthrough" I believe more closely represents the goal

Santiago Pastorino said:

I think we would be good if in this meeting we properly define what we want to accomplish and maybe have a couple of next steps and things that we can start tackling

someone came up with a diagram of "stages", let me find it
yeah I like compilation process walkthrough
Or something along the lines of "the walking tour of rustdoc"
https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/131828-t-compiler/topic/Overview.20diagram
"Example compilation process"?
let's bikeshed the name later
This might not be possible, but I would love to have a small rust program (maybe just a hello world) where we talk about how its compiled from start to finish
^ yes, exactly
exactly
Yeah, I think that's the idea
I also think that it's hard to do that
but we could try
The nice thing is hello-world in Rust includes macros so we can talk about expansion ^^
I think we could adapt the diagram I linked and show the output of the compiler at each stage
I'm just not sure if hello world really captures all aspects of the compiler, but maybe
https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/user_uploads/4715/v8tpIj6bP0te7uXwpaCo48Xv/image.DNXJY0.png
You can't really explain things like e.g. the borrow checker with a hello world I guess
I would guess that a program that shows great stage a doesn't show great stage b
Unless the program is massive :p
Could certainly end up with a collection of very small programs
(Ahem, looking at you rustc!)

Léo Lanteri Thauvin said:

You can't really explain things like e.g. the borrow checker with a hello world I guess

I don't think we should aim to explain all of the borrow checker. I was imagining we only cover the different IRs
like the AST, HIR, MIR, and LLVM IR
and how each gets generated
Frontend, perhspas too
Right. I was wondering how this was different from the "overview" chapter
I think that's covered by the AST

We might want to cover the borrow-checker on something like:

let mut v = vec![1, 2, 3];
v.push(4);
Covering only the IRs seems good to me

Léo Lanteri Thauvin said:

Right. I was wondering how this was different from the "overview" chapter

It will show the output after each step
and go into a lot more detail
In addition to IRs, we want to show TyCtxt too, right?

fn main() {
  let name = std::env::args().next().unwrap();
  println!("Hello, {}", name);
}
Could think of it as an iteration of the the overview. "Now that we've looked at the overview, lets see in action..."
perhaps a good way to define the goal, shape and contents would be to frame the walkthrough in terms of "what questions do we want to answer?" & "what questions will the reader have?"

rylev said:

fn main() {
  let name = std::env::args().next().unwrap();
  println!("Hello, {}", name);
}

Hmm, that looks interesting

Camelid said:

We might want to cover the borrow-checker on something like:

let mut v = vec![1, 2, 3];
v.push(4);

I don't think that should be part of this TBH. That's useful to document, but I don't think it needs to be documented here.
Personally I feel like just showing the IRs is not that helpful
the borrow checker is strictly a restriction
You can already see the IR in the playground
not sure what/how exactly, but definitely let's not fall in the trap of starting to write a walkthrough and ending re-writing a new rustc guide :P
I want to show what is being generated
Okay, I think I see what you mean

Camelid said:

You can already see the IR in the playground

you can't see the HIR or AST, just MIR
so we better define the scope of this
Phase 1, IR generation?

Joshua Nelson said:

Camelid said:

You can already see the IR in the playground

you can't see the HIR or AST, just MIR

True, but we could instructions for people to find it locally with -Z unpretty
I would like to show IRs + important internal state that you can't see normally
I like the idea of introducing TyCtx
Like what types have been inferred

Camelid said:

I would like to show IRs + important internal state that you can't see normally

I like this
Yep. Maybe a let x = 1;
Yep, _internal state_
Might be easier with let x = vec![1] or let x = [1] to show type variables.
True :)
the std::env::args().collect() should work well, that has lots of inferred types
@Santiago Pastorino I think you are the one who proposed this, so what scope did you have in mind?

my feeling is that it may be good to have a tour of the compiler from start to end driven by one (or more) example(s) and showing key structures that the compiler define and how they look like and also showing the output of these parts
I meant, this is up to discussion

Joshua Nelson said:

the std::env::args().collect() should work well, that has lots of inferred types

Yeah, though hopefully it wouldn't be too complex...
but my original intention was that and that's also why I've said that it may be good if we spread this through all the guide and not have just one section

Santiago Pastorino said:

my feeling is that it may be good to have a tour of the compiler from start to end driven by one (or more) example(s) and showing key structures that the compiler define and how they look like and also showing the output of these parts

Once we discuss the scope a bit more, might be worth figuring out now what some of those structures are
but I'm not sure
I guess after we start writing and doing something it will become more clear where to place things
I feel like it might be easier to comprehend it all if it's all in one place
Plus we can always move things
yeah, let's start writing something as a separate chapter because it's also easier
We might want to structure the work in terms of passes.
You mean, start with just showing IR or something?
We do usually use passes IIUC
That way you don't do everything at once
Does anyone else have something to say on the topic of scope? @triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
(we can always come back to this later too)
@Léo Lanteri Thauvin what does :eyes: mean?
ok cool, let's move on then

Camelid said:

Léo Lanteri Thauvin what does :eyes: mean?

Didn't know that command existed :D
So do we want to start getting into the details of the data structures or is there something else someone wants to discuss first?
this is a great question that I also have :)
if we're discussing internal state I would love to peek into the trait system
I feel like we could keep discussing this and trying to plan forever
I've been trying to figure out how it works for ages lol
but my feeling is that we should just start doing something
and figure out from there
I think that's what @pierwill was saying
I liked Joshua's list: AST, HIR, MIR, and LLVM IR
Yep. Yes break that list into the "passes" we discuss in the overview. (I know it's a simple exercise )

pierwill said:

I liked Joshua's list: AST, HIR, MIR, and LLVM IR

:+1: to this, also because I feel like we should just start, there's always time to improve or change things
So perhaps let's do that (AST, HIR, MIR, and LLVM IR) as a first step.
But since we're all here, do you still want to start planning the data structures etc.?

pierwill said:

I liked Joshua's list: AST, HIR, MIR, and LLVM IR

I explicitly left out assembly because I don't think it's particularly instructive compared to LLVM IR
right
Plus rustc isn't responsible for generating assembly

Camelid said:

But since we're all here, do you still want to start planning the data structures etc.?

what do you mean by data structures?
yeah let's leave that for llvm guide
Things like TyCtxt
Or things like BuildReducedGraph Resolver (or something similar) in resolve
I guess we could make a list of important data structures for each different stage

Phase 1: AST, HIR, MIR, and LLVM IR
Phase 2: Type context, ids, dependency graphs
Phase 3: borrow....
(Just a thought)
Maybe "IR transformations"
Like macro expansion?

pierwill said:

Phase 1: AST, HIR, MIR, and LLVM IR
Phase 2: Type context, ids, dependency graphs
Phase 3: borrow....

unsure what do you mean here?
Just a priority list for things to work on, really
I think @pierwill is referring to the phases of writing the chapter
That's the kind of thing that has a direct, visible impact
when you say phase, are you talking about ... ahh right :)
again, I don't think those things belong in the same chapter
let's focus for now on what @pierwill established as Phase 1
If we're going to talk about Resolver, it should be as part of how HIR is generated
not a stand-alone thing

Rough stages:

  1. Lex
  2. Parse
  3. Resolve
  4. Expand
  5. Type-check
  6. Trait-solve
  7. Build MIR
  8. Borrow-check (& other analyses)
  9. MIR-optimize
  10. Codegen: LLVM or cranelift
Honestly I'd love to see even AST -> HIR to start with!
Yeah, it's a big undertaking, so just 1-4 would be great
We might also want to show tokens as a basic "IR"
yeah

Lex
Parse

IIUC these are done at the same time
same for resolving and expanding
Yeah, but they're two separate parts of the compiler
One drives the other, but they're still separate
I guess? they call between each other a lot
The lexer calls the parser?
Conceptually distinct enought, tho

Camelid said:

The lexer calls the parser?

oh sorry I was thinking about expanding and resolving
Just like with query system, the MIR builder is calling the type-checker
you're right that I think the parser is one way

Camelid said:

The lexer calls the parser?

I'd be surprised by this too
lex -> parse <-> resolve <-> expand
So we could start with stages 1-4 and IRs: tokens, AST, intermediate AST for macro expansion, HIR

Joshua Nelson said:

Camelid said:

You can already see the IR in the playground

you can't see the HIR or AST, just MIR

actually it might be nice to add this to playground
I'll open an issue for that
I think people have discussed it before
And someone just needs to do the work of implementation
https://github.com/integer32llc/rust-playground/issues/502
I don't have time today but I would be interested in working on that
maybe as a way to focus our discussion a bit more

Camelid said:

So we could start with stages 1-4 and IRs: tokens, AST, intermediate AST for macro expansion, HIR

What do people think of this? Too much, too little for our first pass?
what if we just talk about one section that we all agree on?
and think of an example and discuss what do we want to show
and by that I meant, the concrete data structures and output and things :)
Yeah maybe we pick a first example program?
Hello world plus a variable assignement?
We might want to just start with hello-world if we're only dealing with lexing through expansion
I would like to get a macro in there somewhere

fn main() {
    println!("Hello, world!");
}
I'd maybe see a condition too
a lot of the complexity of resolve is for dealing with macros
println! is a macro :)
Although it is a somewhat complex one.
Without control flow, the part on MIR is going to be kind of empty :)
Yeah, but our first pass isn't going to cover MIR.
Oh, right, sorry
I guess you're suggesting that we wouldn't want to change the example too much?
Question: How might this chapter benefit someone who understands the basic concepts of rustc, but wants to start hacking...? Is that an intended audience?
Hopefully it would help them get an overview
(Asking for a friend :innocent: )
Because otherwise you're kind of fumbling around in the dark
(I still feel that way about certain parts, like monomorphization and trait solving, as Joshua mentioned)
(more like most of the compiler :sweat_smile:)
what about using matches!?
I think this will be useful for lots of people. Thinking about specific audiences and tasks they might want to complete usually helps me, though
That would get us a macro and a conditional...
And it would be a very simple match statement to compile...
right

pierwill said:

I think this will be useful for lots of people. Thinking about specific audiences and tasks they might want to complete usually helps me, though

I think our goal is to give a bird's eye view of the compiler that is helpful in gaining a general understanding of how it works.

What about something like:

fn foo(name: String) -> bool {
    matches!(name, "Rust" | "Ferris")
}
We don't have to use a binary – and it means we don't need to show the intricacies of println!
That’s a good point
I like it
What do people think about that?
SGTM
SGTM too
Let's just rename foo to is_awesome :crab: :D
(and we can always add an example with a binary later on)
Will a goal be to demonstrate how one might investigate these levels in source that is not the example? Is this summarized in the guide somewhere?
we can show how to generate the IR from the source as part of the chapter
You mean like link to a chapter with detail on the stage?

Camelid said:

What about something like:

fn foo(name: String) -> bool {
    matches!(name, "Rust" | "Ferris")
}

:+1: I was trying to come up with something but this seems good
like show -Z unpretty=hir next to the HIR
Although once we start covering internal data structures, we'll probably have to get the information with debug logging or panicking.
we can keep adding things as we go if we feel some other construction shows something better
^^ yes, if I read through the chapter and want to have a look at a different source it would be nice to know how to approach it. Link out to section in existing chapter or summarized in this one
I was writing an example with an if else but ... whatever :)
We can always add more examples later
We might want to keep a patched version of the compiler somewhere that dumps internal data structures
We could even give people good sample programs to investigate and look into as exercises
Yeah, but I think let's save that for a later pass
Totally

Camelid said:

We might want to keep a patched version of the compiler somewhere that dumps internal data structures

I would rather just make that a -Z flag so everyone can use it

Camelid said:

We might want to keep a patched version of the compiler somewhere that dumps internal data structures

...so that we can apply the patches to a recent version of the compiler without having to start from scratch

Joshua Nelson said:

Camelid said:

We might want to keep a patched version of the compiler somewhere that dumps internal data structures

I would rather just make that a -Z flag so everyone can use it

agreed!
meanwhile we are at this we can add such things
That sounds like a good idea
-Z dump-internal-data or something
(we can bikeshed later)
This flag sounds awesome!
yeah, maybe one per pass or something, there's already things for MIR
I would love to use it myself outside of the guide
-Z dump-ast, etc
Well we can already dump the AST
Oops, I forgot: we can only dump the HIR
anyway, so more or less we have an idea about what to do
Slight tangent: anyone know what -Z unpretty=everybody_loops shows?

Santiago Pastorino said:

-Z dump-ast, etc

(bikeshed: I think -Z unpretty=ast would fit better)
how can we organize the work?

Joshua Nelson said:

Santiago Pastorino said:

-Z dump-ast, etc

(bikeshed: I think -Z unpretty=ast would fit better)

Especially since it would be using the pretty-printer

Camelid said:

Slight tangent: anyone know what -Z unpretty=everybody_loops shows?

the everybody_loops pass: https://blog.rust-lang.org/inside-rust/2020/09/17/stabilizing-intra-doc-links.html#hirids-and-defids-and-trees-oh-my
Do we open issues and assign people?
Probably have a meta-issue and sub-issues
unsure :)
And then assign on sub-issues
So I might be interested in implementing -Z unpretty=ast and then I can be assigned on the sub-issue for that
Personally, I think it might make most sense for one or two people to write up a few paragraphs, and go from there

pierwill said:

Personally, I think it might make most sense for one or two people to write up a few paragraphs, and go from there

I have this same feeling

pierwill said:

Personally, I think it might make most sense for one or two people to write up a few paragraphs, and go from there

Yes, but there's some stuff to implement before writing
like it's hard to split the work until there's something up
Ah, true. Could certainly have a tracking issue :)
I can be on the hook for adding unpretty=hir and unpretty=ast to the playground

Camelid said:

pierwill said:

Personally, I think it might make most sense for one or two people to write up a few paragraphs, and go from there

Yes, but there's some stuff to implement before writing

well I'm not sure, we can start playing with the example and structures and trying to show intermediate things
I might try to implement Z-unpretty={ast,thir}
We could just start with showing HIR and discussing in English how the passes works (without showing internal data)
I could try to do parts of -Z dump-internal-data but I might need help
different idea/approach, would people like to schedule a time, like 1h/2hs where some of us try to work on these things and share ideas?
I'm not sure if I can commit to another 1h/2hs, especially since most people are in a later timezone
I may not be suggesting the most organized ways to do things or best practices, I'm more kind of trying to de-rail everything into chaos style :)
yeah I would prefer to work on this when I have time, I don't think it needs to be scheduled
We still have 15 minutes, we could start sketching a rough draft if people want to try that.
I find I work slower when I'm explaining as I go
Yeah, we can just discuss on GitHub or async on Zulip
And then discuss more at our next scheduled meeting
seems good then
which is...next week!
(Same time?)
No, 9-9:30 I think
(oops, 9 my time)
nope, it starts an our later
Not sure I can make that. But this was fun! Nice to chat with y'all. :)

Santiago Pastorino said:

nope, it starts an our later

That's a better way of explaining it :)

Santiago Pastorino said:

2021-02-23T14:00:00-03:00

this is even better :joy:

ok so

Action items

  • I work on https://github.com/integer32llc/rust-playground/issues/502
  • @Léo Lanteri Thauvin works on -Z unpretty={ast,thir}
  • @Camelid works on -Z dump-internals
does that sound good to everyone?
And people can start writing ideas for first pass of section
seems good to me
I would like to try out some ideas
Thank you @Santiago Pastorino!
like more like playing with structures and things
Can we get someone to create the structure in the guide? I mean just creating the outline of the sections we want to do
more than just literally writing a section :)

rylev said:

Can we get someone to create the structure in the guide? I mean just creating the outline of the sections we want to do

I was suggesting that different people who are interested could come up with draft outlines and then we could mix and match
yeah this is my chaos style :)
Issue: rustc-dev-guide#1062
Feel free to open sub-issues and edit the issue to link to them :)
This will be a very interesting chapter. Definitely something that I want to read. :smile: Will try to pitch in where I can.
I guess the meeting is over or do someone have something else to say :wave: to finish and :loudspeaker: to speak
@triagebot end-meeting :smile:

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.

Léo Lanteri Thauvin said:

I might try to implement Z-unpretty={ast,thir}

Probably thir is going to be hard since it's lazily generated
You might want to just start with the AST since the THIR is probably not going to be touched by newcomers

Camelid said:

Léo Lanteri Thauvin said:

I might try to implement Z-unpretty={ast,thir}

Probably thir is going to be hard since it's lazily generated

I'll start with the AST anyway I think. But I will work on the THIR (implementing unsafety-checking), so I hope that'll help
unsafeck happens on MIR IIRC
it's being moved
https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/233931-t-compiler.2Fmajor-changes/topic/refactor.20the.20unsafe.20checking.20to.20work.20on.20t.E2.80.A6.20compiler-team.23402
Ah, a recent development
Yes, but see https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team/issues/402
Good to know, thanks :)
Okay, see you all on Tuesday! :wave:

Santiago Pastorino said:

2021-02-23T14:00:00-03:00

Time zone? :innocent:
It's shown in your local time zone
You can hover to see an absolute UTC time
